==English== ===Etymology=== From {{suffix|en|dank|en}}. ===Verb=== {{en-verb}} # {{lb|en|transitive}} To make [[dank]] {{q|all senses}} #* {{quote-text|en|year=2011|author=James Howerton|title=The Cold Days|page=196|passage=They set out southward, skirting around the bison, tawny scouts wandering and studying the creatures, how they moved across the land. The rich manure of the herd '''dankened''' the wind.}} ---- ==Dutch== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|nl|dum|danken}}, from {{inh|nl|odt|thancon}}, from {{inh|nl|gem-pro|*þankōną}}. Equivalent to {{affix|nl|dank|-en|id2=denominative}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|nl|/ˈdɑŋkə(n)/}} * {{audio|nl|Nl-danken.ogg|audio}} * {{rhymes|nl|ɑŋkən}} ===Verb=== {{nl-verb}} # {{lb|nl|transitive}} to [[thank]] ====Inflection==== {{nl-conj-wk|dank}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|nl|dankbaar}} * {{l|nl|afdanken}} * {{l|nl|bedanken}} ====Related terms==== * {{l|nl|dank}} ===Anagrams=== * {{l|nl|denk na}}, {{l|nl|kanend}}, {{l|nl|nadenk}}, {{l|nl|nakend}} ---- ==German== ===Etymology=== From {{etyl|goh|de}} {{m|goh|dankōn}}, from {{etyl|gem-pro|de}} {{m|gem-pro|*þankōną}}.
